paragraph: "I shouldn't wonder if you were right, Mrs. Rapkin," said Horace blandly; "you see, you had been exerting yourself over the cooking, and no doubt were in an over-excited state, and, as you say, those camels had taken hold of your imagination until you were ready to see anything that Rapkin saw, and _he_ was ready to see anything _you_ did. It's not at all uncommon. Scientific people, I believe, call it 'Collective Hallucination.'"

paragraph: Altogether, Horace walked to Great Cloister Street that morning in a fairly cheerful mood and amiably disposed, even towards the Jinnee. With all his many faults, he was a thoroughly good-natured old devil--very superior in every way to the one the Arabian Nights fisherman found in _his_ bottle.
tokens: walk great morning cheerful mood dispose many fault good natured old devil superior way one arabian fisherman find bottle

paragraph: "Ninety-nine Jinn out of a hundred," thought Horace, "would have turned nasty on finding benefit after benefit 'declined with thanks.' But one good point in Fakrash is that he _does_ take a hint in good part, and, as soon as he can be made to see where he's wrong, he's always ready to set things right. And he thoroughly understands now that these Oriental dodges of his won't do nowadays, and that when people see a penniless man suddenly wallowing in riches they naturally want to know how he came by them. I don't suppose he will trouble me much in future. If he should look in now and then, I must put up with it. Perhaps, if I suggested it, he wouldn't mind coming in some form that would look less outlandish. If he would get himself up as a banker, or a bishop--the Bishop of Bagdad, say--I shouldn't care how often he called. Only, I can't have him coming down the chimney in either capacity. But he'll see that himself. And he's done me one real service--I mustn't let myself forget that. He sent me old Wackerbath. By the way, I wonder if he's seen my designs yet, and what he thinks of them."

paragraph: "'Um," said Beevor, "you've got along very well alone so far--at least, by your own account; so I dare say you'll be able to manage without me to the end. Only, you know," he added, as he left the room, "you haven't won your spurs yet. A fellow isn't necessarily a Gilbert Scott, or a Norman Shaw, or a Waterhouse just because he happens to get a sixty-thousand pound job the first go off!"

paragraph: Then Horace understood. His indefatigable Jinnee had been at work again! Of course, for Fakrash it must have been what he would term "the easiest of affairs"--especially after a glance at the plans (and Ventimore remembered that the Jinnee had surprised him at work upon them, and even requested to have them explained to him)--to dispense with contractors and bricklayers and carpenters, and construct the entire building in the course of a single night.

paragraph: "No, sir!" shouted the infuriated Mr. Wackerbath; "since you ask my opinion, it's nothing of the sort! It's a ridiculous tom-fool cross between the palm-house at Kew and the Brighton Pavilion! There's no billiard-room, and not a decent bedroom in the house. I've been all over it, so I ought to know; and as for drainage, there isn't a sign of it. And he has the brass--ah, I should say, the unblushing effrontery--to call that a country house!"
tokens: sir shout infuriate ask opinion sort ridiculous tom fool cross palm house be billiard room decent bedroom house know drainage be sign have brass say unblush effrontery call country house

paragraph: Horace's dismay was curiously shot with relief. The Jinnee, who was certainly very far from being a genius except by courtesy, had taken it upon himself to erect the palace according to his own notions of Arabian domestic luxury--and Horace, taught by bitter experience, could sympathise to some extent with his unfortunate client. On the other hand, it was balm to his smarting self-respect to find that it was not his own plans, after all, which had been found so preposterous; and, by some obscure mental process, which I do not propose to explain, he became reconciled, and almost grateful, to the officious Fakrash. And then, too, he was _his_ Jinnee, and Horace had no intention of letting him be bullied by an outsider.
tokens: dismay shoot relief genius courtesy take erect palace accord own notion arabian domestic luxury teach bitter experience sympathise extent unfortunate client other hand balm smart self respect find own plan find preposterous obscure mental process propose explain become reconcile grateful officious have intention let bull outsider

paragraph: "Let me explain, Mr. Wackerbath," he said. "Personally I've had nothing to do with this. This gentleman, wishing to spare me the trouble, has taken upon himself to build your house for you, without consulting either of us, and, from what I know of his powers in the direction, I've no doubt that--that it's a devilish fine place, in its way. Anyhow, we make no charge for it--he presents it to you as a free gift. Why not accept it as such and make the best of it?"
tokens: let explain say have do gentleman wish spare trouble take build house consult know power direction have doubt devilish fine place way make charge present free gift accept such make good

paragraph: "Make the best of it?" stormed Mr. Wackerbath. "Stand by and see the best site in three counties defaced by a jimcrack Moorish nightmare like that! Why, they'll call it 'Wackerbath's Folly,' sir. I shall be the laughing-stock of the neighbourhood. I can't live in the beastly building. I couldn't afford to keep it up, and I won't have it cumbering my land. Do you hear? _I won't!_ I'll go to law, cost me what it may, and compel you and your Arabian friends there to pull the thing down. I'll take the case up to the House of Lords, if necessary, and fight you as long as I can stand!"

paragraph: "Don't go, sir," said Mr. Wackerbath, as he scrambled awkwardly to his feet, his usually florid face mottled in grey and lilac. paragraph: "It is," said Horace. "And so am I. I don't want to reproach you. I quite feel that you have acted with the best intentions; but, oh, hang it all! _can't_ you see that you've absolutely wrecked my career as an architect?"
tokens: say want reproach feel act good intention hang see wreck career architect

paragraph: "That is a thing that cannot be," returned the Jinnee, "seeing that thou hast all the credit."
tokens: thing return see hast credit

paragraph: "The credit! This is England, not Arabia. What credit can I gain from being supposed to be the architect of an Oriental pavilion, which might be all very well for Haroun-al-Raschid, but I can assure you is preposterous as a home for an average Briton?"
tokens: credit credit gain suppose architect oriental pavilion assure preposterous home average

paragraph: "Yet that overfed hound," remarked the Jinnee, "expressed much gratification therewith."
tokens: overfed hound remark express much gratification

paragraph: "Naturally, after he had found that he could not give a candid opinion except on all-fours. A valuable testimonial, that! And how do you suppose I can take his money? No, Mr. Fakrash, if I have to go on all-fours myself for it, I must say, and I will say, that you've made a most frightful muddle of it!"
tokens: find give candid opinion four valuable testimonial suppose take money have go four say say make frightful muddle

paragraph: "Acquaint me with thy wishes," said Fakrash, a little abashed, "for thou knowest that I can refuse thee naught."
tokens: acquaint wish say little abash refuse naught

paragraph: "Then," said Horace, boldly, "couldn't you remove that palace--dissipate it into space or something?"
tokens: say remove palace dissipate space

paragraph: "Verily," said the Jinnee, in an aggravated tone, "to do good acts unto such as thee is but wasted time, for thou givest me no peace till they are undone!"
tokens: say aggravate tone do good act such waste time givest peace undone

paragraph: "This is the last time," urged Horace; "I promise never to ask you for anything again."
tokens: last time urge promise ask

paragraph: "Not for the first time hast thou made such a promise," said Fakrash. "And save for the magnitude of thy service unto me, I would not hearken to this caprice of thine, nor wilt thou find me so indulgent on another occasion. But for this once"--and he muttered some words and made a sweeping gesture with his right hand--"thy desire is granted unto thee. Of the palace and all that is therein there remaineth no trace!"
tokens: first time make promise say save magnitude service hearken caprice find indulgent occasion mutter word make sweep gesture right hand desire grant palace remaineth trace

paragraph: "Another surprise for poor old Wackerbath," thought Horace, "but a pleasant one this time. My dear Mr. Fakrash," he said aloud, "I really can't say how grateful I am to you. And now--I hate bothering you like this, but if you _could_ manage to look in on Professor Futvoye----"
tokens: surprise poor old think pleasant one time dear say say grateful hate bother manage look

paragraph: "What!" cried the Jinnee, "yet another request? Already!"
tokens: cry request

paragraph: "Well, you promised you'd do that before, you know!" said Horace.
tokens: promise do know say

paragraph: "For that matter," remarked Fakrash, "I have already fulfilled my promise."
tokens: matter remark fulfil promise

paragraph: "You have?" Horace exclaimed. "And does he believe now that it's all true about that bottle?"
tokens: have exclaim believe true bottle

paragraph: "When I left him," answered the Jinnee, "all his doubts were removed."
tokens: leave answer doubt remove

paragraph: "By Jove, you _are_ a trump!" cried Horace, only too glad to be able to commend with sincerity. "And do you think, if I went to him now, I should find him the same as usual?"
tokens: trump cry glad able commend sincerity think go find same usual

paragraph: "Nay," said Fakrash, with his weak and yet inscrutable smile, "that is more than I can promise thee."
tokens: say weak inscrutable smile more promise

paragraph: "But why?" asked Horace, "if he knows all?"
tokens: ask know

paragraph: There was the oddest expression in the Jinnee's furtive eyes: a kind of elfin mischief combined with a sense of wrong-doing, like a naughty child whose palate is still reminiscent of illicit jam. "Because," he replied, with a sound between a giggle and a chuckle, "because, in order to overcome his unbelief, it was necessary to transform him into a one-eyed mule of hideous appearance."
tokens: be oddest expression furtive eye kind elfin mischief combine sense wrong do naughty child palate reminiscent illicit jam reply sound giggle chuckle order overcome unbelief necessary transform eyed mule hideous appearance

paragraph: "_What!_" cried Horace. But, whether to avoid thanks or explanations, the Jinnee had disappeared with his customary abruptness.
tokens: cry avoid thanks explanation disappear customary abruptness

paragraph: "Fakrash!" shouted Horace, "Mr. Fakrash! Come back! Do you hear? I _must_ speak to you!" There was no answer; the Jinnee might be well on his way to Lake Chad, or Jericho, by that time--he was certainly far enough from Great Cloister Street.
tokens: shout come hear speak be answer way time great

paragraph: Horace sat down at his drawing-table, and, his head buried in his hands, tried to think out this latest complication. Fakrash had transformed Professor Futvoye into a one-eyed mule. It would have seemed incredible, almost unthinkable, once, but so many impossibilities had happened to Horace of late that one more made little or no strain upon his credulity.
tokens: sit draw table head bury hand try think late complication transform eyed mule seem incredible unthinkable many impossibility happen late more make little strain credulity

paragraph: What he felt chiefly was the new barrier that this event must raise between himself and Sylvia; to do him justice, the mere fact that the father of his _fiancée_ was a mule did not lessen his ardour in the slightest. Even if he had felt no personal responsibility for the calamity, he loved Sylvia far too well to be deterred by it, and few family cupboards are without a skeleton of some sort.
tokens: feel new barrier event raise do justice mere fact father _fiancée_ mule less ardour slight feel personal responsibility calamity love deterre few family cupboard skeleton sort

paragraph: With courage and the determination to look only on the bright side of things, almost any domestic drawback can be lived down.
tokens: courage determination look bright side thing domestic drawback live

paragraph: But the real point, as he instantly recognised, was whether in the changed condition of circumstances Sylvia would consent to marry _him_. Might she not, after the experiences of that abominable dinner of his the night before, connect him in some way with her poor father's transformation? She might even suspect him of employing this means of compelling the Professor to renew their engagement; and, indeed, Horace was by no means certain himself that the Jinnee might not have acted from some muddle-headed motive of this kind. It was likely enough that the Professor, after learning the truth, should have refused to allow his daughter to marry the _protégé_ of so dubious a patron, and that Fakrash had then resorted to pressure.
tokens: real point recognise change condition circumstance consent marry experience abominable dinner night connect way poor father transformation suspect employ means compelling renew engagement means certain act muddle head motive kind likely learn truth refuse allow daughter marry _protégé_ dubious patron resort pressure

paragraph: In any case, Ventimore knew Sylvia well enough to feel sure that pride would steel her heart against him so long as this obstacle remained.
tokens: case know feel sure pride steel heart obstacle remain

paragraph: It would be unseemly to set down here all that Horace said and thought of the person who had brought all this upon them, but after some wild and futile raving he became calm enough to recognise that his proper place was by Sylvia's side. Perhaps he ought to have told her at first, and then she would have been less unprepared for this--and yet how could he trouble her mind so long as he could cling to the hope that the Jinnee would cease to interfere?
tokens: unseemly set say think person bring wild futile raving become calm recognise proper place side tell first unprepared trouble mind cling hope cease interfere

paragraph: But now he could be silent no longer; naturally the prospect of calling at Cottesmore Gardens just then was anything but agreeable, but he felt it would be cowardly to keep away.
tokens: silent prospect call agreeable feel cowardly keep

paragraph: Besides, he could cheer them up; he could bring with him a message of hope. No doubt they believed that the Professor's transformation would be permanent--a harrowing prospect for so united a family; but, fortunately, Horace would be able to reassure them on this point.
tokens: cheer bring message hope doubt believe transformation permanent harrowing prospect unite family able reassure point

paragraph: Fakrash had always revoked his previous performances as soon as he could be brought to understand their fatuity--and Ventimore would take good care that he revoked this.
tokens: revoke previous performance bring understand fatuity take good care revoke

paragraph: Nevertheless, it was with a sinking heart and an unsteady hand that he pulled the visitors' bell at the Futvoyes' house that afternoon, for he neither knew in what state he should find that afflicted family, nor how they would regard his intrusion at such a time.
